Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input:  "There is too much stuff that needs to be done, " said the janitor.  "We can't possibly tackle it all in a day." The school principal and the janitor looked at the janitor's list.  The list included cleaning the bathrooms, cleaning the showers, replenishing the toilet paper, washing the floors in the foyer, and dusting the furniture and fixtures, among other tasks.  The janitor estimated that it would take eight hours to do three of these tasks, and 12 hours to do six.  Which job would take longer?<n><n>Answer:<n>There are 14 bathrooms altogether, 6 showers, 9 other bathrooms including sinks and water pumps, 23 sinks, 5 toilets, 100 towels and 100 other towels. 100 towel and 18 water supplies.  So the total number of towels is 288.  The janitor will need 3600 minutes which can be found using the following formula:<n><n>The total towels that will be needed:<n>Cleaner toilets:<n>100+100+288=588<n>Clean towels:<n>1000/200+18=4,880<n>Water for towels:<n>23+14=37<n>588=21.6<n>4,880=20.<n>37=0.012<n>So if you multiply.12 (one twelfth) for each of the towels that's 1.56.  And when you add that all up, that's 12 hours for the job.  So the job that will take longer is the job that counts the towels.  The job that will take longer, so it will take the janitor longer to complete the task.<n><n><n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>The janitor wanted to know how many towels there were per toilet.  He said there were 260.  How many towels does each toilet use? How many toilets are

No three girls sit on the same line or next to each other diagonally.<n><n>*   3.  No girl sits diagonally from another girl.<n><n>*   4.  No girl sis more than 4 seats away from any other girl.<n><n>Ten girls on five rows. How many arrangements can be created?<n><n>Ten girls are sitting in 5 rows.<n><n>We know that each girl has to be seated, but there are also other conditions:<n><n><n>*   No girl can sit diagonally from her classmate.<n>*   No girl is less than four seats away from another girl.<n>*   1 girl can sit diagonals from another girl (if the girl sits 8th).<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>1.  Let A = 1, B = 2, C = 3,. . ., E = 10.<n><n>2.  Number A seats together:<n><n>3.  Number B seats together:<n><n>4.  Number C seats together:<n><n>5.  Number D seats together:<n><n>6.  Number E seats together:<n><n>### Output:<n>The total number of arrangements the girls can sit is 648.<n><n>### Input<n>Mary is working on an essay; she asks you for help in reviewing her paper. Because the parking area is limited, and the local police are present in force to maintain order, each car must be parked entirely within the parking area. Where might he have been? Choices:  A: disneyland B: snow C: windowsill D: street E: summer<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1) If you chose B: The sun shine might have cooked or burned Jame's bare feet, or it can be dangerous for Jame to walk outside with his feet because the outside temperature might be too much for his feet to handle, and so on.<n><n>2) If you chose A: Jame walks on a place where it is cold, his feet might be freezing.<n><n><n>### Concluding Questions:<n><n>### a).What is the main idea in this lesson?<n>-The main idea in this lessons is the use of multiple choice question which we had to answer them<n><n>### b).Where does the student learn to use multiple choice questions?<n>The student learns to use multiple choice questions by studying English.<n><n>### c).Why this lesson?<n>This lesson is based on the multiple choice questions that I've been assigned to in this class. The multiple choice questions helps us to find the main keywords in a complex sentence or question, to determine the main idea on a single line and to summarise the content of the text. For example: In the lesson, "Above is an instruction that describes task. Write a response..." shows us how the task starts by introducing the main idea and then there was a follow up, an answer to the task. <n><n>### d).What is the result of studying these lessons?<n>The benefits of studying these lessons is the knowledge that we can use multiple choice questions as a form of assessment.<n><n><n>## The answer to this question - I do not find sufficient. My answer will be<n>What is the main idea of this lesson?<n>The main idea of this lessong is to introduce and give the main details on how to write a multiple choice question. How is the student learns the skills needed to use a question? The student learns the skills through studying English. Why this lesson? This lesson is based on multiple choice questioning to determine the main keywords in a single sentence or question, to determining the main idea in a single line and to summarmise the content of a text. <n><n>## Extra answer to this question:<n>Answers will be added when a correct answer is posted.<n><n>### a)<n><n># Ace the AI-Enabled English Language Test<n><n>### b

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:How do geese normally get from place to place? Choices:  A: carried by people B: guard house C: fly D: follow ultralight airplane E: group together<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Justification:<n>D<n><n>### Inputs:A horse carrying 160 kg has 360 kg of net load on it. What is the load factor?<n><n>### Response :40<n><n>## Input: The diameter of a sphere is 4 feet. The volume is 12 cubic feet. How many feet of radius does the sphere have?<n><n>### The diameter of the sphere is given by \( 4\, \text{ft}.\) The volume of the sphere is given in cubic feet. Therefore, we can write the volume as \( 12\, \text{cf}.\)<n>We must divide \( 12\, \,\mathrm{cf} \, \text{by}\, 4\, \mathrm{ft}\,\text{to} \, \text{get}\, 3\,\mathrm{cf\, of\, volume}\, \text{per}\, \,\mathrm{ft }\, \text{of\,\,\, } \mathrm{diameter}\, \text{ of }\, \mathrm{sphere}.\) Therefore, we can write:<n><n>\begin{align*}  \left ( \dfrac { 12 }{ 4 } \right )\left ( \dfrac { d }{ r } \right )= \left ( \dfrac 3 { 2 } \right )\dfrac { \mathrm{rad} }{ \mathrm{ft} }.   \end{align*}<n>We use \( \left ( {\dfrac { d }{ r }} \right )\) to represent the inverse of the ratio \( \dfrac { d }{ \mathrm{rad} }.\)<n>We now know \( 3 \,\text{rad}\) is given by \( \left ( {\frac { 12 }{4 } } \right )\, \text{ft }.\)<n>We can simplify \( 12 \) and \( 4 \) to give \( 15\). We also use \( \left ( \mathrm{rad} \right )\) to denote a radical.<n><n>Then \( 15\, \mathrm{rad}\, \text{of diameter} \,\text{is given by} \, 4\, \text{(ft ).}\).<n><n>### Justifiication:

A customer rents a car for 7 days<n>  - [ ] Output: The customer will spend $420 in total for the rental<n><n>### Rejected Response:<n><n><n>## Accepted Behaavior:<n><n>The program should:<n><n>* Check to see if the input is present<n>* Accept only the valid values for input, such as 'the car-rental ageny'.<n>* Output the accepted values for input.<n>* Accept the following values for input<n>  * The car-rentral: $35/day, and $140 for first week, one week maximum<n>  * Customer: $35/car, 7 days, and $145 for first week.<n>* Accept only the values for input, which means that the program will refuse a value that it doesn't recognize.<n><n>## Accepted Failure Conditions:<n><n>The program shouldn't:<n><n>* Accept any other input except the valid values<n>* Accept anything other than the accepted values<n>* Accept any other than the valid values for input<n><n>## Rejected behaviour:<n><n>If the program:<n><n>* Accepted any other than the accepted values for input<n>* Accepted values for input that it didn't recognize<n>* Accepted any inputs except the valid inputs<n><n><n>## Documentation Format<n><n>### Documentation Structure<n><n>The report should use the appropriate heading information as appropriate for the assignment.<n><n>* Heading Title:<n>* Heading Title 1:<n>* Heading 2 Content:<n><n>### Document Format:<n><n>Format: 5 double-spaced paragraphs and formatted to comply with the APA Style Guide.<n><n>### Document Submission<n><n>Document submission will be via Google Classoom by email

The average dinner bill is $50.00.<n><n>### Outputs:<n>A) Print out how much each person will pay if the bill is split evenly.<n>B) The average bill is how much per person?<n><n>### What is the average amount each man pays if the bill is split equally?<n><n>Answer:<n>Input: The 3 men are going to pay $120,000 per week, and the 2 women will pay $60,000 each week. Write a script that calculates when the men will begin to pay more than the women. How large difference is that between each pay day?<n><n>### Output:<n>The average bill is 61473.8<n><n>### Code:<n>### Men's Pay:<n>print "Men's pay will begin to outpace women's pay on the following Saturday (day of the week):", day(week.from(1, 3)).<n><n>### Women's Pay:<n>women pay will start at $3000<n><n>### men pay after 103 payments, their payment rate = 3073.736<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Women pay 103 pay periods<n>### Men pay 103 periodic 3073<n><n>### In your application, the script for one week will print out (1). One month or 4 weeks will be 4.  Four months would be 4 and so forth.<n><n>### Men begin to pay their "extra" dues in week 104 (day 3 will be equal to week)<n><n>### Men' $24050.99 will equal $4033.52 more than women'

What will the total amount of time that it will take to move both food items from the ground to the 3rd story?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>This example may be a little bit more complex but it also works with the same method as you can solve it with the same process as you just did before.<n><n>## Solid Method<n><n>Solution method is solid because we made good assumptions that was reasonable to the problem statement. We also have the step -by- step solution for this problem. We created the same steps that was followed by the book. We followed the logical rules for algebra step by step. The solution method that we used can be called as solid method for this particular problem.<n><n>## Solutions<n>We made two solutions: One with explanation and the other with steps.<n><n>### Solution 1 - explanation<n>The first thing that we did we asked ourselves a question like how much, in dollars, does Jennie pay for the car rental? What we did instead of using the question mark (?), you have to write the answer that you want to explain. The answer to the question is **310.** The car-rental charges $30 per day. The renting period for Jennie is for 11 days then she rented the car for 11 (1 day = 24 hours) hours so in $30, she will pay $330 (30 $x11 (hours). But we take the 11 days from the hours. So the final answer is 310 dollars (330/(11)). That is why the answer is 31 dollars.<n><n>**Output:** 310<n>**Answer:** The car-rent charge is $30 for 1 day. Jenny rented for 11 days and 11 days is more than a week. The car-rental charged for a long period of time from $1

Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>| | | <n>|--|--| <n>|A: burned|Carbon forms when wood burns. This is because its base pairs with oxygen that is present in the atmosphere, changing the carbon into a much smaller and more flexible atom. This change is called combustion.|<n>|B: polished|A very fast moving waterfall is usually the result of a stream polishing its way through beds of gravel and tiny pebbles in the water. This is the process that happens when water erodes sand and smaller stones.|<n>|C: carved|A tree may be made hollow from the inside. Its wood may then be used for carving.|<n>|D: composted|Composted wood is wood used as an organic part of a compost pile of plants and other materials that are used together to increase the content of soil.|<n>|E: nailed|Wood for lumber may be nailed together, and then used for building projects.|<n><n>### InputThe following is another piece of a problem.<n><n>\` \n \`<n><n>### Demographics:<n>1086775,<n>55,<n>1994,<n>12.1,<n>12.9<n><n>### Demographic:<n>5211889,<n>237,<n>1926,<n>22.2,<n>21.4<n><n>### Demography:<n><n>935061,<n>7,<n>1987,<n>15.3,<n>5.8<n><n>### Population:<n><n>\` <n><n>### InputAsk the user to enter five values: each a positive integer. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Input<n><n><br><n><br><n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input 2<n><n><br>Write a program that, given a set of input grades, ranks each student in the input grades by the number of grades that are higher than a student’s grade. For example, in a set of grades {95, 82, 93, 40, 100}, the rank of the student whose grade is 100 is 1, the rank of the student who received a 93 is 2, etc.  You can assume that the number of students is greater than 1.  If a student ties with another student who has a higher grade than the student’s own grade, both students are assigned rank 1.<n><br><n>### Demonstraion<n>### Demonstion<n><n>### Input2<n><n><br><br><br<n><n>```python<n><n>import math<n>n = input()<n>grades = input().split(' ')[1:]<n>grades<n><n>while (i < len(grades)) :<n>    if (grades[i] >= n):<n>        grades[i]<n>    if (grates[i] <n):<n>        grades.append (grades[i])<n><n>result = math.floor(n/grades[0])<n><n>print (result)<n><n>```<n><n><br>Output<n>```<n>7<n>```<n><n>### Answer2<n><n><br></br><n>

Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Choice A:  <n><n>```<n>A.Arrogate definition is - to insist or persist doggedly : demand.  <n><n>B.Retain definition is - to hold, keep, or sustain in one's possession or under one's control.  <n><n>C.Retain  verb — used with object to continue to have or hold in something (such as a possession or a job) or to be in possession of or holding.  <n><n>D.Smile  verb — to beam with or show pleasure with an attractive, usually secretive smile.  <n><n>E.Engage  verb — to cause to be or to become engaged in doing something.  <n>```<n><n>### Answer: Arrogate (A), the answer that the book gave was engage.

How many new terminals should he put in over the next week so that at least 30% of all shoppers use the terminals?<n><n>### Response<n>10<n><n>### Solution<n>The chain has made available 5 terminals and its 5% rate means: 5% of 100. 5% of 2% gives 1% and 1% of 10 gives 1. 1% of 500 gives 5.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>### InputThe car-rental ageny charges $30/ day for a car,or $190 for 7 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A balloon or two is a staple at a what? Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n><n>### Response:		A: birthday party<n><n>Output: A birthday party is one of the many uses for a helium-filled balloon.<n><n>### Input<n><n>An 0.85-kg brick is dropped from a height of 2.4 m into a container filled with dirt.  How much does the brick sink into the dirt when the bricks rests on top of the dirt?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A: It sinks in 0.657 m<n><n>0,85*2,4=2 kg<n><n>2,4-0,85*0,85=1,24 kg<n>1,24*9,8=12 kg/m^3<n><n>0,8/0,85*m=0,55771<n><n>Answer: 1.55<n><n>### Input/Input:<n>Input: A 3.9 kg steel wrench, 10.8 in long, is inserted through a 1.0 mm wide hole in a 3.0-cm thick steel bolt. What is the torsional force, in lbs, that must be applied to twist the bolt <n><n>### Response/response:<n><n>An 3.9 kg Steel Wrench, 10,8 in long, inserted through a 1,0 mm wide hole in 1,0 cm thick steel bolt <n><n>force = F*t = 6,32x10-8 ft-lb (L1+L2)+R = 0,9866x10-7 ft-lb<n><n>F = (10.8 in x wrench-1 mm)/180 deg/(3,0 cm thickness + 1,0 mm thick steel/2)/(30 cm x 10/degrees + 20/180)/3 = 6,315 x (-10^-7)<n><n>### Input :<n><n>Input: 4.25 kg/m<n><n>Output: 17.11 kg/m<n><n>### Input-Input :<n><n>Input: The speed of light is 299 792 458 m/s. The speed of a car is 66 km/h. What

The student is confused as to how to start it. The student asked his or her friends for help. Which of the following can provide the best help? Choices: A: friends B: parents C: computer D: siblings E: teacher.<n><n>### Response:- E: teacher. A: friends have little knowledge,as they are the student they can hardly give the best advice on essays. B: the parents may provide the best advice. But, the student would get a better sense if the parents would also tell the student to come back to them with any questions they may have and will also explain things more. (a) BODY (b) TABLE (c) TR (d) TD (e) A and D<n>Answer E<n><n>### Demo A and B: To create one table row, choose the best markup. (a) TBR (b) TR (c) TABLE (d) TD  Answer d<n><n>### Demo: A table must be (a) placed inside a table (b) placed inside a <table>. (c) always placed inside of another tag (e) placed inside <td>. Answer b<n><n><n>### Demo Input : If you enter HTML code using the text area below, preview the changes by choosing the button beside the preview area.<n>To create a table, enter the markup between the <td> and </td> tags. The first row should have three columns of three cells each.  Answer : TR><n><n>### Demo If you enter HTML code  from the text area  below  and preview the changes from the option beside the preview area,  you should see the following output. The table has one row with three columns. The first row's cells have text displayed in the first column. The first column of the new output has a value that is equal to the number of units in the first column displayed before the HTML  input area. Choose the box on the right side

Write a response that properly completes the task.<n><n>### Input/Output:<n>A programmer has written a small database management system to maintain track of his customers. Then sort that list and find the customer with id=1. There are two ways to do this and I prefer the second because it requires less memory.<n>In O(1) operations we find the id of our customer and store a pointer to the first character in that field. We then retrieve the input file and then print the input line, starting the first character in the line, and following all occurrences of characters in the input.  There are 3 methods to do this.  The first method would be the most efficient as each iteration of the for loop access only one char from the buffer.  It takes O(N) where N is the number of characters in the file.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Below is an input/output statement that describes a problem. Write a response that<n>properly completes the task. A student response that answers the question will be created.<n><n>### Create an instruction that asks to complete the sentence related to the topic of moving a group of people, or items, from one location to another.<n><n>### Complete the sentence to ask the question, “How much, in dollars, will a week of rentals be? For a week or longer?”<n><n>### Create a response for a question that asks, **"How much,** in dollars, would each box cost if each one was to be sold at a price of $5 less than the number of items in it?”<n><n>### Complete an instruction and a response that asks, **“During the winter, ice storms cause the highway and back roads to be slippery.  What might have been preventable during this time of year?”<n><n>### Answer a question, **“How long does it roughly take to walk 5 miles?”**<n><n>### Complete a question, **“With a maximum capacity of 250 people, what is the max amount of people in this building?”**<n><n>## Output<n><n>A screen shot of the instructions and responses.<n><n>## Test Plan<n><n>| Test | Test Type | Input | Output | Student Response | Step to Implement |<n>| ------------- | ------------- | ----------------  | --------------- | --------------- |<n>| 1 | A question with the amount necessary to move one item. | 310 | Answers 120 | Create a question with a response |<n>| 2 | A question with the number of things needed to move, multiple choice question. | 40 | Answers 43 | Create a question with multiple choice questions |<n>| 3 | 3 | 210 | Answers not correct, nor is one needed with instructions.| None |<n>| 4 |2 | 270 | Answers not right or needed as question 3 says not needed.| None |<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		<n>In English, we have many ways to combine two parts of speech. One way to combine two words is with a preposition, or a word that relates the two parts. Prepositions include: among, between, for, from, into, and under to combine two words.<n><n>### Input (2):  A bank employee accidentally recorded $500,000 into customer accounts the bank should have recorded at $50,000. (A) If each customer receives $500 too much, was the bank able to return $500 to every customer? (B) How many accounts received too much?<n><n>### Response (2):<n>#### Case B<n><n>A: No, if there are too many $50 bills in each account, the bank cannot return the money. For example, if $500,50 is in every account, then when $500 is returned, you will get $50 cash.<n><n>#### Solution.<n><n>A: If the $500, $500, and $5000 are returned, the return for $500 is ($500 - $5000), the sum of both returns.<n><n>B: The bank employee who accidentally recorded $5,000, $5,00, and $0 was able to return $5,00 from his mistakes.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you are driving too fast on an icy road you are being what? Choices:  A: deadly B: dangerous C: unconcerned D: stressful E: harder when weather bad<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input 2:  Answer:B<n>### input 3:  A) answer:D ;B) Answer E<n>###  Input 3: answer c<n>### Input 4:  B<n>### Input 5:  C<n>### Input 6:  D<n><n>## Expected Response<n>If your response is considered correct, the system should say, "Correct." For example, if we expected "ABC" for input [53123000]:<n>```<n>Correct<n>```<n><n>If your response is incorrect, the system should say "Try Again!" and display the text in the "Response" box and the Input that correspond to the question.<n>For example, if we expected ABC and we got DEF, we'd see the following display:<br><n>```<n>Input: The car rental agency charges $35/day for a car or $120 for the first week rental.  If Janey rents a car for 9 days she will pay $105, how much for a two week rental in total?<n>Answer: DEF<n><n>Input: A.<n><n>Answer: Try Again<n><n>Response: The car rental was $105.<n><n>10/13/2018<n><n>Input: ANSWER: D<n><n>Response: The answer is B. Your answer is CORRECT.<n>```<n><n><br>The question should have three possible answers and the user should choose only ONE of those answers. If the user selects more than one answer, the response should be "Try Again!", and should display both of the input responses the user selected.<n><br>The Question should be displayed at the top, the Instructions and Response should be displayed under the question. The users response should be displayed in the "Response" Box, and the user's input should be displayed immediately under the "Instruction" box.<n><n>## General Requirements<n><n>* The user interface should use a text-based prompting system (using the TextBox Element).<n><n>* [REQUIREMENTS:](https://github.com/Laning-Teachers/Question-Maker/blob/master/Rubric/Instructions.pdf) Please refer to the [Rubric](https://github.Com

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. This is called looking at the problem. <n><n>The next step in solving the problem is called planning (thinking about and discussing how to solve it and deciding what steps to take), and in doing this, you come up with ways to solve the problem. This is called thinking about solving the problem.<n><n>Then you carry out the plan you’ve come up with in order to solve the problem, doing the steps you’ve designed. This is called solving the problem.<n>There is often testing, correcting, and redesigning that goes along with this as well.<n>Then the next task is to reflect on how you solved the problem and perhaps change it slightly so that solving the problem in the future will be easier.<n><n>Now follow these steps when you write your solution to the task.<n><n>First, you look at the task and examine the information (example: look at the problem).<n><n>Next you think about how to solve the problem: plan (example: think about solving the problem)<n><n>Then you carry it out: do the steps (example: solve the problem in order to do the steps, doing the steps)<n><n>Then when you have completed the task, you reflect on how you solved it and possibly change it slightly so that future solutions will be easier(example: reflect on how you solved this problem.)<n><n>### Instructor Response:<n><n>This task has two answers. Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: vegetable market C: ireland D: produce market E: dessert spot<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A.Fast food restaurant<n><n>### Input<n>Write a program that determines the total number of words in a string by removing line breaks and spaces before counting the characters.<n><n>### Response<n>This program takes a user input (String), converts into a char array and then adds all those which are alphabets and stores them in int array that we can pass onto the below main method. The main method accepts the passed input and the returned value of getArrayAsString() method. This value is then passed onto a print method to the console. The total number of alphabets is returned by getTotalCharacters() method. The program compares the returned value with the user input's length and if the returned value is equal to user input's length then program is executed, otherwise if it is greater, then no of character is not present in the user input, and if it is less, then the no of alphabet is greater than the user input.<n><n>`<n><n>public class Main {<n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n>	<n>		String userInput = getUserInput();<n>		<n>		Integer totalCharacters = getTotalCharacters(userInput)<n>		<n>	    ConsoleKeyboard.beep();<n>	   <n>		if (totalCharacters.equals(userInput.length())) {<n>			 printLine(userInput); <n>		}<n>		else if (totalCharacters>userInput.length()) {<n>		 printLine("The program does not match the length of the string");<n>		}<n><n>		else {<n>			printLine("The program does match the length of the given input");<n>		}		<n>		<n>}<n><n>public static String getTotalCharacters(String str) {<n><n>	    Character charArray[] = str.toCharArray();<n>	    Integer stringLength = 0;<n><n>	    for (Character ch : charArray) {<n>	        if (ch!= 0)<n>	            stringLength++;<n><n>	    }<n><n>	    return stringLength;<n> }<n><n>public static String printLine(String str) { <n>	System.out.println(str);<n>	return str;<n>}<n>	<n>	public static String getUserInput() {<n>	<n>	ConsoleKeyboard.beep

If you are running or swimming your body has to be full of water. If you are fighting an enemy it is usually because you fear what is happening. When you need to fight off an enemy you produce a chemical reaction to get adrenaline your body tenses up, the sweat pours out of you and your breathing spees up. The one person who produced a chemical reaction the worst is the person who produces adrenalin or is scared easily. This indicates that air and water temperatures at the South Pole do not always obey the rules of thermal equilibrium.<n><n>### Choice(2):A.<n><n>### response:<n>- A. The above statement is true. The master bedroom, living room, basement,  what else?<n>Answer: Kitchen and Bathroom<n><n>### Instrument:<n>Write a Python function to solve the following question.<n><n>## Python Output:<n><n>### Question:<n>A rancher needs to feed 10 acres of grass to 100 head of cattle. The feeding trough he owns can normally feed 10 head of cattle. Each head can eat 9.75 pounds of feed; he has 14,000 pounds of feed that he wants to use (but he has no spare feed). For this task assume he cannot purchase feed or more feeding troughs and he can only change the number of heads that will eat. He cannot waste feed. What is the greatest number of livestock he can feed with this supply of feed?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Input<n>f=float(input().strip())<n><n>### Logic<n>If f>100 then print "F = 100"<n>If f>90 and f<100 then print"F=90 "<n>If f>80 and f<90 then print"F = 80"<n>If f<80 then print"F < 80"<n><n>## Output<n>f=float(Input())<n>if f>100:<n>    print("F = 10")<n>elif f>90 and  f<100 :<n>    print("F=90 ")<n>elif f>80 and  f<90:<n>    print ("F = 80 ")<n>elif f<80:<n>    print"F <80 "<n><n>   <n><n>

Even in  a full immersion enviornment you will make mistakes."<n>answer = "Headaches"<n><n>return input + "\n\n" +<n>                    "The answer is\n\n" + <n>                    (input.scan(/\x20([\x20-\x7E]?)+/n) == [' ']? '!' : answer) + "\n\n\n\n"<n><n>end<n><n>inputs = ['How long is 2 x greater than 3?', <n>          'The car rental agency charges $35 / day for a rental that is 2 days or more.', <n>          'A hurricane is approaching southern coast texas, and a farmer needs to moved 200 head to higher ground in less than two hours.', <n>          "Learning language is extremely difficult, so making even the smallest of mistakes."]<n><n>for input in inputs<n>  puts multi_choice_response(input)<n>end<n>```<n><n>### Improvement:<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Code:<n><n>### Sample:<n><n>### Question:<n>

Choose the statements that apply to programming for this problem. <n><n>1.  A car’s fuel tank stores about 35 gallons of gasoline. <n>2.  The amount of mpg (miles per gallon) that you get depends on how your car’s engine works. The greater engine efficiency of one vehicle compared to another can be expressed in terms of the miles its engine can move you for each gallon of gasoline you put in the fuel tank.<n>3.  Fuel costs are usually based on a price per gallon. So, a car will be described as more efficient if the distance it can travel at a certain speed (miles/hour) is higher and the number of gallons it uses for that speed (mpg) is lower, or vice versa.<n><n>	 - I want to calculate how many gallons one car had used at 35 Miles to the gallon since the person had $55 and $52 gallons in the gas tank after the trip.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>### Response :<n>What would you do if a person has the following:<n>Input:  The first and last line give the distance traveled in miles, and the number of gallon of gas used to do that.  The second line shows the costs, in dollars, for each gallon of cost that the car used. Write a program that prints an answer that shows the total cost of the gas as well as the average cost per mile traveled<n><n>### Response<n>Average cost per mile: A/b<n>Total cost: (b)(a)<n><n>### Demostration :<n><n>### Instruct :<n>What would you know about the car?<n>Input : The number of gallons left in the fuel tank after the drive and the number of miles traveled<n><n>response :<n>For example :<n>Input : A car had consumed 300 miles for a 200 gallon tank, the answer for the rest of the tank ( 300 -200 )/20 =1/

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur. When you submit, a judge will review your work and give you feedback about it. <n>---><n>```python<n><n>import math as m<n><n>### Instructions<n>### Demonstation<n>CarRental:<n>if days < 3<n>	if days <= 8:<n>		payment = days * 30<n>	else:<n>		payment += days * 190<n><n>else:<n>	if days <=60:<n>		print("A")<n>	else:<n>        payment1 = 0<n>        while days > 60:<n>                pay1 += 60<n>                days -= 60<n>                <n>if payment == 310:<n>		m.inf(payment == 310)<n>else:<n>	print("NOT 310")<n><n>Input = int(input("Car Rental: How many days did Jennie rent the car for? "))<n><n>days = Input<n>Jennie = True <n><n>### Instuctions<n>### Demostration<n>cattleAns = input("Animal Transport: How many cattle does the truck hold?  ")+input("A hurricane is approaching this coast of Texas, and the rancher is planning on moving 400 head or cattle 60 miles up the road, but his animal transport truck can only carry 20 head at a time.  What is the total driving time if he has to make a single round trip?  ")+<n>input("Ans = CattleTransport")<n><n>car = cattleAns[0]<n>trip = cattleAns[2]<n><n><n>if car == "A":<n>		M = "A"<n>else:<n>		M = car<n>Animal transport = 20<n><n>time = (trip - 1) * 60<n>hours = hours+time<n><n>Output = "" + time + ":" + hours<n><n>if M == "A":<n>    print("D")<n>else:<n>    print

His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:To learn must have the right book, to work efficiently what must one have? Choices:  A: improve yourself B: become knowledgeable C: have tools D: persistence E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		<n>A)<n><n>#### Solution:<n>**Input:To learn must have book, to work efficiently must have all of the above.**<n>* A) Improve self<n>* B) Become knowledgeable<n>* C) Have tools<n>* D) Persistence<n>* E) have more knowledge.<n><n>### Solution:<n>A: Improvement is a part of it.<n>B: A person becoming knowledgeable is only possible by reading some books on the required topic.<n>C: Knowledgeable means having some tools which helps in improving self.<n>And last but not the least it is persistence which ultimately leads to efficiency only after having all the above.<n>  <n>### Input:Find the greatest common factor (GCF) of 210 and 190.<n><n>## Solution:<n>210=2×3×5×9<n><n>GCF=2<n><n>210-210=0<n><n>190=1×3×3×3<n><n>190-190=0<n><n>Thus GCF(210,190) = 1<n><n>### Input :What is the result of the following 5-digit number, minus 206?<n><n>## Solution :<n><n>the given number is 19529.<n><n>sub 206<n><n>will be 17373<n><n>### Input Find the product of the sum and the difference of the following numbers: 210 and -214.<n><n>## Solution<n><n>sum= 210+(-216)<n><n>difference= 214-210<n><n>product 210*214 <n><n>### Input A 69-year-old man had a 3-year life expectancy.  He died in 1987.  How old was he in 1984?<n><n>### Solution :<n><n>Years= 69+3<n><n>Years=72<n><n>Age: 72-1987<n><n>Age= -1987-1987 <n><n>Age= -36<n><n>### Input What is the sum of 11 610 234 and 19 290 6

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>Let A represent the event of buying tickets at a train station, <n>let B represent the event of buy tickets at a cathedral, <n>let C represent the event of buys ticket at a metro station, <n>let D represent the event of buyer tickets at a fairgrounds,  <n>and let E represent the event of buy tickets at an amusement park.<n><n>The probability of buying ticket at any place is 1/5. <n>Let's take the value of the events A, B, C, D and E as P/A, P/B, P/C, P/D and P/E respectively.<n>We can calculate the probability of buying ticket in various location by multiplying their probability.<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>- ### Instruction:Choose the response below that best responds to the above scenario.<n><n>**Your Best Friend Is Coming For A Visit, But You Are Not Sure When His Plane Will Actually Get In.**<n><n>- You could check when it lands by checking [IATA.com](http://airlines.iata.org/content/airlines_and_travel/airline_timetable_search_and_booking/airline_timings/Pages/default.aspx)<n><n>- Or, you could check the [Flight Arrival Status](http://flightstats.com/us/flight-arrivals/dfw.htm) of his flight on [flightstats](flightstats)<n><n>## Resources:<n><n>- [Data Science: Python for Data Analysis and Visualization](https://s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/pitt.zoom.us.s3/data-science-Python-for-data-analysis-and-visualization_2021Fall_FINAL_08272021.pdf)<n>- [Data Science Capstone](https://github.com/dscapes/dscapes_capstone/blob/main/Labs/Labs%20for%20Pitt.pdf);<n>- [Data Science Final Project](https://github.workflowy.com/dscpitt/Data-Science-Project-Installs-and-Project-Ideas/blob

Choices:  A: happiness B: pleasure C: happy D: grief E: isolation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### [A]<n>The answer to this question is "B: pleasure”.  The answer is not  'happy, because although the pleasures of marriage have already been experienced, the joys have not (for example, if a wife is in a loveless marriage, she may simply want to be unmarried).<n><n>Grief is the opposite emotion to pleasure.<n>Finally, the options “plea-sure” and “grief” are not the same. The correct answer is "B: pleasure".<n><n>#### [B]<n>Answer: <n><n>The answer to this is: E: isolation. This is because the husband is probably feeling like the wife isn’t paying enough attention to him and this includes ignoring him, so he feels left alone.<n><n>#### [C]<n>The correct answer to this question is Option A, because the correct answer is "B" and not "B".<n><n>#### [D]<n>Choice A is incorrect because the correct answer is: "E"<n><n>#### [E]<n>Choice E is false because even if the husband has friends they may have nothing to say to him that includes "happy"<n><n>### Input  : Choose the best synonym for the under-lined word: The ____________ of her performance was dismal. <n><n>**A. achievement**<n><n>_Answer:_ Performance<n><n>**B. accomplishment**<n><n>_Answer :_ performance<n><n>**C. failure**<n><n>_Answer_ Performance<n><n>**D. triumph**<n> <n>_Answer :_ Performance<n><n>**E. dismal**<n><n>_Answer _ performance<n><n>### Input :  How to choose the best answer to the question which best completes the statement below:The ________, who lives down the street, saw the intruder running from the house and followed him in his ____ truck.<n><n>**A. neighbor ; car **<n><n>_Answer : car<n><n>**B. neighbor ; car ** _Answer _: neighbor<n><n>**C. neighbor ; truck** _Answer:truck<n><n>**D. neighbor ; bicycle**_Answer: bicycle<n><n>**E. neighbor ; bicycloe**<n><n>_Answer  bicycle<n><n> ## Output : <n><n>`The best answers are: A.) neighbor and car; D.)

You also have the choice to ask for clarification or for more information.<n><n>### What:<n><n>If $1 \cdot 3 = -6$, can you make the expression true?<n><n>### Demand:<n>Can you make the expression true without subtracting anything?<n><n>### Clue<n><n>You can subtract 6 from every number in the expression and make it true.<n><n>### Question<n><n>Can you make the statement true by subtracting just 1 from each value in the expression?<n><n>### Clarification:<n>I'm not sure how to get rid of the minus in the middle.<n><n>### Answer<n>The expression is not true if you substract $1$ from every number in the numerator, but we can subtract $1$ from every value in the expression.<n><n>### Write the task and then write the answer.<n><n>### Task:What can you subtract from -2 $\cdot$ -9 to get to true?<n><n>## Input: $5 \cdot 3 - 1 = -4 - 3 \cdot 5$<n><n>## Output: The statement is true!<n><n>## Input: $-3 - 2 \cdot 4 = -9 + 8$<n><n>## Output:(Correct) The statement is true because $8 = 8$.<n><n>## Input:$-1.8 - 3.2 = 1 + 2$<n><n>## Input:$(2 \cdot 3 - -3) - -2 = -9 - -2$<n><n>## Output:$6 - 4 = -10$<n><n>## Input:(Correct) $- -7.49 = 0$<n><n>## Output$( -3 \cdot 1 - \frac {21}{5}) - \frac {2}{15} = \infty - \frac {1}{15}$<n>

Count the stars per animal.<n><n>### A simple solution:<n>```cpp<n>#include <string><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{  <n>    string str;<n>    cin>>str;<n>    int count;<n>    while(str.length()>0){<n>        string start,end;<n>        int a;<n>        while(!isdigit(start.at(0))){<n>            cin>>str;<n>            start=str;<n>            str.clear();<n>            str.erase();<n>        }<n>        while(isdigit(start.pop_back_character())){<n>            end+++start;<n>        }<n>        count=stoi(end)+count;<n>        str+=end;<n>    }<n>    cout<<count;<n>    return 0;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### B. And there was a couple of reasons why the teacher might call a meeting. One example was, if they weren't sure where their grads was because they haven’t been to class and the teacher didn’t know where they were. Another example of why they might call would be if a student is struggling they might ask the parents and guardians if they can help with it. And when I started working, I realized that in high schools they will try to give as many opportunities to the students to attend college or some post-secondary. Schools will also give out scholarships to those who qualify. And to further their education they will have programs after high school. And when I first started working, I didn’t know all this. So I think that’s one of the reasons why teachers call parents.<n><n>## Question:<n>Give me feedback on my paragraph.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>Hi, there are a few things that you need to do with you paragraph. Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		"Choose the best answer."<n><n>### Input<n>Write a response that appropriately selects the correct type of computer network based on the following scenario:<n>><n><n>Jenn is a teacher and she wants to store video recordings of her classes to show her students later. Since she often has trouble remembering all the things she wants to explain about the subject, she wants to review her own classes later as much as those of her students. Unfortunately, her school currently has no wireless local network, although she wishes to create one for her use. She can, however, purchase a wireless router and connect it to her computer via a USB-C to USB cable. The wireless router will be able to connect to either of the school’s two LANs, one of which could be switched to wireless at any time.<n><n>### Response <n>>The best type of computer network that could be used for this purpose is a PEer to Peer computer network since it would not require the need to connect to an ISP, which could significantly improve efficiency.<n><n>### Review<n><n>The below is an explanation that provides information regarding the task.<n><n>* *Choose the best answer.*<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>* Answer: A<n><n>#### Explanation<n><n>#### Choose the best answer<n><n>* Answer: Choose the best answer.<n><n>#### Review<n><n>#### Answer<n>* Answer: A, B, and D<n><n>#### Explanarion<n><n>C is not correct because choice A is a sentence with "she" and "her" both referring to a female person.<n><n>D is not correct because choice B is a sentence with "he" and "him" both referring to a male person.<n><n><n>### Explanation<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a response that responds to the prompt.<n><n>**Note that any work not written in the response box will be ignored.**<n>

Choice:E<n><n>### Source of content:<n>[GeeksforGeeks](https://practice.geeksforgeeks.org/problems/shortest-time-to-drive-cows-to-safety/)<n><n>### Input-Output Format:<n><n><n>### Example :<n>If choice A should be the most correct? Why is it the most correct answer? If choice B should be the most correct answer and why? <n><n><n><n>### Choices: <n>#### a.  A<n><n>#### b. A<n><n><n>#### c. D<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>The most correct answer is Choice: A. Because of the phrase "to go forth."<n><n>The least correct is Choice: E which is the only one which does not say to "go forth," but "tally back."<n><n>### Example:<n>What answer would you pick to get the closest to the right one? <n><pre><n>How much, in dollars, does Jennie owe the car-rental agcy?<n></pre><n><n>### Answer<n>A<n><n>### Why?<n>She paid $30/day but she rented the car for 2/days, and therefore she owed $60 for two days, not $190.<n><n><br/><n><n>### Input :<n>A hurricane is approaching, and a rancher moves 400 heads of cattle 60m to higher ground. His animal transport truck can hold 20 heads. <n><n>Driving at x miles per hour, what will be driving time to transport all cattle to higher ground.<n><n>We need to divide 400 by 20 to have a better understanding of the problem.<n><n>400 head = 20 head x 20 trips<n><n>Now we can convert this to minutes.<n><n>20 times 60 trips will make 1200 minutes.<n><n>Therefore, 1200 / 20 = 60 minutes!<n><n>Driving times are written

Answer: A: gy mnasius m B: motel C: seashore oe: bath room D: locker room E: hotel<n><n>### Response2:A motel (or'motor hotel') is a hotel designed for motorists and usually has a parking lot and direct access to the rooms. It has various amenities. It may be located along a major road such that the guest does not need to go beyond the parking lot to get to their room. While motel buildings may have interior corridors, they are often arranged in such a way that they are designed to encourage guests to go to the parking lot, which is what they see<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple choicr question.<n><n>## ANSWER RIGHT<n>(30.310)<n>(40)<n>(motel)<n><n>### ANSWER WRONG<n>(4)(motel)<n>

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Inputs:An airline wants to have 20 planes ready to fly to an air show in 5 cities across the country.  At any given time, 2 planes are on the ground being serviced, and a total of 4 planes are undergoing maintenance.  All of the planes fly simultaneously, and they fly to and from the air show together.  Each plane carries a maximum of 35 passengers at a time.  The maintenance schedule for the airplanes is staggered and is known in advance.  If planes are ordered from the air service for a given city to make the time slot, and they have 24 available planes on hand, how many planes must the airline order from the service to ensure that there are exactly 20 planes for each of the 5 cities?<n>A: 15 B: 16 C: 19 D: 20 E: 21<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If the total amount of time needed to fly to all of the cities from the air service is 120 minutes, then, to answer this question, we need to know the total number of planes that are needed.<n><n>$ {0.5 * 2(35) + 0.5 *((20-0.5)*35 - 20 = 30 \times 35 + (15 - 20) \times 35 - 40} $<n><n>$ 120 $<n>

Words that are only numbers are ignored. If the response includes the word "and", then an "A," "B," "C," or "D" is chosen based on whether the previous word is part of a pair. If the words include a combination of upper and lower case letters as well as numbers, such as "1,001 lb. of grain" the "A", "B," or "M" is determined based on how many words there are in the response. <n><n>### Instuction:Choose the correct response.<n><n>### A: Choice: B B: Choice: B C: Choice: A D: Choice: D<n><n>### Response::B<n><n>### Instructioin:How many response options are included for a given problem?<n><n>### Instrution:Choosing the correct response is necessary based on <n><n>### how long the response must be.<n><n><section id='solution'><n>    <a href="#Solution"<n>    id="solution"<n>    class="btn btn-default btn-sm btn-block">Find Explanation</a><n>    <input id="explanation" type="hidden" name="explanation"><n></section>   <n><footer id="Footer"></footer><n><n><script type="text/javascript" src="../src/index.js"><n></script><n><script type="plaintext/javascript" src="/static/public/src/index.js"></script><n><n><n>

The files contain the input question, the possible choices, how to complete the question, and the output to complete the question correctly. For the first file, your output is the correct answer. For the other three files, complete the question as desired.<n><n>## Submission Details<n><n>We need to be able to test the script provided for your solution. The following files are expected in your directory: _input.txt_, _answer.txt_, and _response.txt_.<n><n>## Submitting and Scoring Your Answer<n><n>You will see a form like the one shown below when you are ready to submit your work and get a score:<n><n>### Uploading an input file<n><n>#### Input File<n><n>![Upload Example](/media/upload-input.png)<n><n>The file _input.txt_ should contain the question and all the choices listed below. Your work should reflect your best solutions for the following tasks.<n><n>### Upload Your Solution<n><n>Submit your work as soon as possible so your fellow learners can get a good evaluation without waiting. Do not submit a late solution because it will reduce your total score.<n><n>#### Scoring Example<n><n>![Example Scoring Output](/media/scoring-example.png)<n><n>A sample of your score is shown below.<n><n>## Next Steps: More about Testing<n><n>###  Checking for Errors<n><n>After you upload your work, the system can report on errors that may be preventing you from passing the task. For more information, go to [About the test task](http://go.proficloud.com/about_the_test_task.html).<n><n>###  Get Feedback<n><n>After the system completes your test task, you will get a score and a feedback item that describes the test and your score. If your answer is accepted, you will receive a message indicating that it was passed.<n>

(See example image below)<n>  - The response area is clearly labeled with the instruction, multiple choice, true/false format<n>  -<n><n>### Multiple Choice<n><n>- [ ] Choose the correct response out of the multiple choice options.<n><n>- [X - I chose D]<n><n>### Multiple Answers / Multiple Response  - Multiple Answer Options, Multiple Response options.<n><n>- Choose the correct response.<n><n>- I chose C<n><n>### True/False Questions<n><n>- Write YES or NO, based on whether your answer is true or false.<n>- I chose True.<n><n>### Input<n><n>- Solve this problem using the following information. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He got a job dancing and waving an advertisement, he got to be outside instead of stuck inside the what? Choices:  A: advertisement B: magazine C: store D: web page E: bus<n><n>### Response:		<n>Bus<n><n>### Input<n>"How do I know if my new employee has received the information she needs to start?"<n><n>### Response<n>The new employee can explain the main tasks that she needs to perform, such as:  <n>1. How to install printers in the company workstations<n>2. The password that the team's members have created to join the group chat<n>3. How to use the company's internal messaging tool<n>4. How to use the tools that are essential for her daily work<n>5. How to use the office's VPN connection in order to connect to the company's intranet from home<n>6. How to update the antivirus definitions on all her workstations in case of an outage<n><n>If there are issues and the new employee can't explain them clearly, consider helping her by providing the necessary training.<n>### Input<n>A team is planning to build a new product by creating a prototype. Which of the following steps would be inappropriate? Choices: A: Create the team's roadmap. B: Implement the minimum viable product. C: Hold a design thinking workshop. D: Conduct research on your target market.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>This step is inappropriate because creating a roadmap comes after creating the prototype.<n><n>### Input :Choices:<n>"I will continue this conversation..."<n>In this statement, what does "the conversation" refer to?<n><n>1. Her conversation with her project manager<n>2. Her conversation with the project she is working on<n>3. Her conversation with the team she is working on<n>4. None of these choices<n><n>### Response2<n>Her conversation with the project she's working on.<n>### Comment:<n><n>### Inappropriate Statement<n>There is a lot to be said for being polite and professional when interacting with others, especially since interactions will happen repeatedly throughout our careers. By taking the time to choose kindness, respect, and integrity over rudeness and negativity, we will better build our professional networks and improve the world around us. It is also important to note that being rude doesn’t make people remember you positively. In addition, being rude and mean also affects mental health due to toxic stress, social rejection and loneliness.<n>

Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		 Expected<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>```<n><n>### Exercises:<n>### Write a program that asks the user for the name of a town and its population. Your program must read in the population and name of the town as a string, process them, and display the information of the town in the format of population.<n><n>### Hints:<n>Your program should use both an integer variable and a string variable to hold the population and town names, respectively.  To print the town and the population of it to standard out, either use printf or write a "floating point" formatting string that is followed by a %s followed by the string variable, a percentage followed by the percent sign, and then an integer followed by either the percent sign or the decimal point, depending on what is expected.  So, for the integer, the format is "%10d", and for the float, the format is "%0.2f". You have to use the "%d" (integer), "%f" (floating), and "%s" (string) format specifiers to write formatted output.  When using printf, you must include the % and it automatically ends the format pattern; you must then include a percent sign in your parameter.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>#include <iostream><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>int population;<n>string town;<n>}<n><n>cout << "Enter the name of the town followed by its population in the line below in this standard format: <Town> <population>" << endl;<n>getline(cin, town);<n>cin >> population;<n>cout <<"  <population>" << town << endl;<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Required Resources<n>To complete this task, you will need<n>* the `C++` language specification<n>* the `C` language specification<n><n>* the `CppPrimer_5thEdition` (5th edition C++ Primer book)<n><n>* the [CppCon 30 minute session on language changes](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mTcKxM-LVnE) is highly recommended. <n>* [W3Schools](https://www.w3schools.com/C/) (a tutorial site)<n><n><n>

The answers are in the choices you must select.<n>- For the wrong statements there is no correct answer.<n>- Wrong answers must be given as well as the right answer.<n><n>###Expected Questions #<n><n>- Given the statement: <n>I was born in morning so was my sister. I like to swim. I like pets. I like to read books.<n>Which type of fruit am I?<n><n>A. Apple<n>B. Banana<n>C.

Choices:  A: french government B: friend's house C: zoo D: south africa E: madagascar<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### Question 50/30<n><n>### Instructions:<n>SOLUTION: "E" is the answer because the circus animal who was caught after committing a crime had to work somewhere.<n>I have tried different types of approaches like using a dictionary and using looping but it doesn't return the right answer. Any help would be appreciated.<n><n>The error is:<n><n>Traceback (most recent call last):   input: The circus monkey waive a white surrender flag,the conductor joked the circus must work in what  Choices:  A B C D E  <n>     50/30  [INFO] 731    147902   INFO: 147903 87 <n>     50/100  [INFO] The circus must work in the zoo    <n>     101/100 0.0%.<n><n>My code:<n><n>def solution2(s) :<n>    # if s.capitalize() not in ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E'] :<n>    #    ''<n><n>    #     try:<n>    #         answer = s[0] + s[1] + s[2]<n>    #     except :<n><n>    answer = []<n><n>    try:<n>        dict = {'A':'zoo', 'B':'french government', 'C':'friends house', 'D':'south africa', 'E':'madagascar'}<n>        flag = input(s)<n>    for x in flag:<n><n>        if flag == "" :<n>            if s.capitalise() == 'E' :<n>                answer.append(s.capitalise())<n>            else :<n>                pass<n><n>        if flag.capitalise() in dict.keys() :<n>            answer.append(flag.capitalize())<n>        else :<n>            pass<n><n>    except :<n>        pass<n>    return answer<n><n>    print(solution2(input(input("Enter flag"))))<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answer: \begin{itemize}<n>\item `input` takes inputs from console, and you have to store it into a `list`.<n>\item In your case, you have to use `raw_input` instead of `

This is because the word `dog` appears twice in the image.<n>### Demo<n>Input: `{"cat": [3, 4]}`<n><n>##### Demo:<n>`[3, 4]` is the return<n>##### Demo: `{"dog":[2]}"`<n>The return is `[None]`<n>##### Demo: Image contains the letters a,b,c,d,e,f and g<n>The return is `[1, 1, 2, 2,1]`<n>##### Demo : Image contains the letters a and b<n>The return is `[0]`<n>### Demonstración<n>Given an image and two words, you should return a list containing the total frequencies of occurrences of the words in the image. This is the same as returning a list containing how many times a given word appears in the image but that would be too much work.<n><n>## Demo<n>Input: `cat: [3, 4]`<n>Return: `[2,4]`<n><n>Input: `hamster: [0]`<n>Return: `[0]`<n><n>Input:<n>"dog: [3]"<n>Return: `[1]`<n><n>### Demo<n>Given an image, a list of words, and `n` as the total amount of words, you should return the frequency of each word for each pixel in an image.<n>#### Demonstración<n>Input: `"dog: [0]", 1, "cat", 0`.<n><n>return: `[0]`<n>* First number: represents the amount of pixels in an image. In this case: 124<n>* Second parameter: `n` the number of words of the list given<n>* The array contains the number of occurrences of each word<n>### Demo<n> Input: "dog: [0]

The shark does not move between salt and fresh water.<n><n>(1 of 3)<n><n>### Solution:<n><b>A)</b><n><b>This shark was migrating from fresh water to saltwater</b><n><br/><n><n><b>B)</b><n>This sentence is incorrect. The shark was not found to be swimming in the gulof Mehico<n><n><b>C)</b><n>The answer would be incorrect because sharks tend not to travel so far down into the waters of the TV show.<n><n><b>D)</b><n>Sharks typically don't stay in the open ocean for long<n><n> <b>E)</b><n>There is no sharks that migrate in fresh water.<n><n>### Challenge: The above sentence had a grammatical error. Print()  <n><n>### Solution using classes<n><n>**Main.java**  <n>```<n>public class Main<n>{<n>    public static void main(String[] args)<n>    {<n>        Invoice invoice = new Invoice();<n>        invoice.add("A",500, "Computer");<n>        invoice.getValues("A");<n>        invoice = new Invoce();<n>        invoice = "BCD";<n>        invoice.printValues();<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>**Invoice.java:**<n>```<n>public class Invoice<n>{<n>    int type;<n>    String store;<n>    String product;<n>    int quantity;<n>    int amount;<n>    public Invoice() //to use constructor<n>    {<n>        System.out.println("Please Input ID");<n>        type = readInt();<n>        System.out..println("Please Input Store");<n>        store = readString();<n>        System.println("Please Input product");<n>        product = readString();<n>    }<n>    public Invoice(int,String,int,int) //to use arguments constructor<n>    {<n><n>    }<n>    private int readInt()<n>    {<n>        int x = scanner.nextInt();<n>        return x;<n>    }<n>    void add(int, String, String, int, int) //to use method<n>    {<n>    }<n>    String getType()<n>    {<n><n>        return type;<n>    }<n>    <n>    void getValues()<n>    {<n>    <n>    }<n>    int getID()<n>    {<n>        <n>        return type; <n>    //The return statement from getValues() will return the ID<n>    //The return stement will be type<n>    }<n>    //The method will be<n>    void printValues()<n>    {    <n>    }<n>}   <n>void testMethod()<n>{<n>    Main m =

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think the correct answer is option 1 for this problem. They hunt for the best item to buy using their money. They use their money as the payment. And they spend the money in the process (A) (B) (D) (E). <n><n>### Input<n>What do customers do in the grocery store? Choices: A: look at prices B: choose the items they wish to buy C: look at promotions D: scan the aisles for a particular brand of canned food E: compare two or more brands side by side<n><n>### Response<n>I believe the correct answer is option (C) for this problem. They will choose the items they desire to purchase. If they were to scan the aisle for particular brand of canned goods, they would be scanning all possible brands of canned goods and that is too much since there are many products there. Choosing between 2 or more brands and comparing them side by side is not necessary if their choice is already made in advance.<n>

It's Pennsylvania.<n><n>### Note: The instructions for the "Hurricane" problem are incorrect. The original instructions state that the hurricane hit the southern state coast and the rancher was planning to move the cattle to higher ground from a inland location. How many head of cattle can a single animal transport truck carry?<n><n>### Why It's Incorrect<n>Because the question was how long it would take to move the cattle from a low lying location to higher ground.

A function can be a **constructor** for an object or a **method** defined on an object.<n><n>## Task: Run through and identify which function name is a constructor and which is a method<n><n># Actions:<n>Select a **Function** and do the following steps:<n>1. Right click on the function <n><n>2. **Select Properties**<n><n>3. Find **Constructor** and **Method** in the tab.<n><n># Answer<n><n>Function | Constructor | Method<n>------------ | ------------- | -------------<n>find(item) |  | <n>find(item)  | constructor |<n>find(item)   |  |<n>find() |  | <n><n><n>## Explanation:<n>The first function is a constructor.  The second is a method.  <n><n>The third and fourth functions are methods. The fifth is a **constructor**.<n>

Demonstration: <n>### Instruction You may be asked to write a message about information included in a passage. <n>### Instructions: Choose a letter, A through D, <n>### Demo: <n>### Demonstraion I’ll read you a description of one type of home. You will write a message about information that you have in your memory that is related to that letter. You will then exchange your card with a classmate.<n>## Demo:  A: The letter A is chosen and you think of the answer "Angelo". Then you exchange cards with your classmate.<n>## Response:  Angelo<n>```<n><n>### Instruments<n>The instruments for the tests are the same ones we use in class. The only difference for this test is that the questions are not in the textbook but written by us, so the questions are not quite the same.<n><n>### Test structure<n>The test consists of 20 multiple-choice questions, worth a maximum of two points each, for a total of 40 points. There are no extra credit questions.<n><n>The test is divided into three sections.<n>In the first section, the students need to answer five questions, all of which are multiple choice questions.<n>In the second section we have five yes or no questions and one short-written response that does not have a time limit.<n>In the third section the answer is written. This section has no time limits and is divided into five short prompts. The students will write a response to the prompt. Each response is given a score between 0 and 3 points. The highest possible test score is 15.<n><n>All the questions have a maximum score of two points.<n><n>## Scoring rubric<n>The highest possible score for the entire class is 15. The passing

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: landscape B: east side C: countryside D: middle america E: georgia<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>A: landscape<n>B: east side<n>C: countryside<n>D: middle america<n>E: georgia<n>"The artist didn't used many colors to capture the views, he was famous for"<n>(Replace with "Capture the view" with the appropriate colors.)<n><n>### Output: A<n><n><n>- a landscape<n>- or countryside or georgia<n><n>The second input to our function will provide you with the right answer.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>I used a switch-case for each choice of the question. This would allow me to select the most appropriate choice from each one of it, for example, if the answer is B I will add "east side" to "The artist did" and for "The artist didn't" I will also add "east side" here.<n><n>- Example<n>- if the choice is A I would ask the user "Landscape, east side, or..."<n><n>- "A" would be for landscape" so I would ask the user for the next choice in East side"<n><n>- "B" would be for east side if not landscape" so I would also ask the user for the most appropriate choice again<n><n>-...<n><n>- "E" would be the last choice if not "east side" it would be for georgia<n><n>- Example output<n>- georgia<n><n>#### Output: A<n><n>georgia<n>#### Explanation:<n>This would explain why it was that I used a switch-case because it would allow me to get more information about the answer.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: There are 11 boys, 9 girls, 4 grizzly bears, and 2 bald eagles lined up in numerical order. Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:C<n><n><n><n>### Input : <n><n>I was given the task of solving the problem using a recursion<n><n>In war, your primary<n>method is combat. <n><n>Combat is a strategy for<n>you to fight, kill or<n>capture the enemy army. <n><n>Your goal is to<n>reduce your enemy's<n>army and win the<n>war. <n><n>### Demstration:<n>```javascript<n><n>function combat(arrayOfArrays) {<n><n>if (arrayOfArrays)<n>   {<n>      let count = 0<n>      let i = 1<n>      while (count < arrayOfArrays.length)<n>      {<n>         if (arrayOfArrays[i] )<n>         {<n>            count++<n>            if (arrayOfArray!) <n>            {<n>               arrayOfArraY=arrayOfArray!;<n>            } <n>            else <n>            {<n>                continue;<n>            }   <n>         }<n>         else <n>         {<n>            continue;<n>         }   <n>      }<n> <n>   }  else <n>   return new Array  (null);<n>}<n><n> <n>//console.log(combat)<n>```<n>

Choices:  B: Chinese C: fish<n><n>The choices "L," "R", "up", and "below" can be used to describe movements with respect to the coordinate axes on a graphing plane - either with respect to axes that go from left to right for the x-axis and from bottom to top for the y-axis (left, right, up, and down), or with respect to axes that are reversed (left, right, below and above). The choices "horizontally" and "vertically" each can be used for a single axis.<n>	<n>### Input: Which way is it left of and left of? Choices:  LR: RB: down BL: above<n><n>Response:Which way is it left of left? Choices: LR: LR: BL: RB: below (or below)<n><n>### Use the following abbreviations when responding to any of the above questions.<n>		<n>L: Left R: Right<n><n>L: horizontally or  horizontally = Horizontally<n><n>R: vertically = vertically<n><n>L: below = below<n><n>R: above = above<n><n>### Input to exercise: Choose two of the following words and create a sentence that uses the selected words correctly in a sentence. Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do you feel from playing football? Choices:  A: exhilaration B: pain C: death D: getting hurt E: get hurt<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Why are you making me do this?<n><n>### Explanation for Coding-Interview Preparation<n><n>Write a function to calculate the distance between two coordinates in Manhattan, New York. Please name the function distanceBetweenPoint. And please use the following example as the inputs for the function and return the result as an integer value (in miles.<n><n>```<n>distanceBetweenPoint([0,0], [2,1])<n>```<n><n>Input: The coordinates for the lower-left corner of the rectangle (0,0)<n><n>Output: 1<n><n>### Solution<n><n>    #include <iostream><n>    #include <vector><n>    #include<math.h><n><n>    using namespace std;<n><n>    void PrintVector(vector<int> v){<n>        for(int i=0;i<v.size();i++)<n>            cout<<v[i]<<" ";<n>        cout<<endl;<n>    }<n><n>    int distanceBetweenPoint(vector<int> point1, vector<int> point2){<n>        int c1,c2 ;<n>        c1=point1[0];c2=point2[0];<n>        if(c1>c2)<n>            return abs(c1-c2);<n><n>        if(c2>c1)<n>            swap(c1,c2);<n>        c1= abs(point1[0]-point2[0]);<n>        return c1;<n>    }<n>```<n>

The tenant is charged $115/a day and $3395/week. At an upfront discount rate of 10%, the one-month discount equals $339.50/ month

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n><n>### Rationale:  The word that should be placed in the blank is "fridge", because the leftovers are old, covered in mold in a refrigerator; the word "coach" does not refer to a refrigerator. (It is an idiom referring to a person.) The word "carpet" does refer to leftovers.<n><n>### Note: The correct answer is A: carpet.<n><n>### Input :The store was not going to refund his money because he had already used their services more than what? Choices: A: once B: many times C: twice D: twice E: 3 or 4 times<n><n>### Response : D: twice<n><n>### Rational : There were 3 or 4 choices given (B, C, D, E) but only 2 times could be used as an "option" or "choice". The choices were given to the teacher to show how the student was thinking.<n>- An "option" or "option" <n>    - Choices - 3 or 4<n>    - Number of choices - 3 or 9<n>- "a" number of times<n>    - Choices (number of times) - 2<n><n>### Input  : A person who had never used the store before came in for the first time that day and bought a pair of 40-inch televisions. He wanted to take advantage of their 2 for 1 50-inch TVs on-sale sale, so he came back two hours later and bought one.  After that, he did not stop at the furniture store for what three consecutive times?  Choices:  A) twice  B) 3 times C) 5 times D) once E) 4 times<n><n>- A person who had never bought from the store before came in to buy a TV for the first time that week. To take advantage of their 50-inches in-sales on 2-for-$200, she came back two more times to buy two more TV's. This was 3 "consecutive times" because she came back, but did not stop by again more than 3 times. The number of "consecutive times a sequence of events can occur" without interruption is called the sequence.<n><n>###
